title: Yet another toothbrush holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Yet another toothbrush holder. Inspired from others seen around. Bigger upper holes to accommodate larger toothbrushes, and holes below to drain the water.

Notes:

Prints in two pieces. They should fit together nicely. If not, feel free to modify the model using the source files provides (Geomagic Design / Cubify Design or whatever that software is called nowadays).
A low infill density (around 30%) should be enough, but in order to ensure structural integrity consider setting a relatively large wall thickness (1-2 mm).
Print with whatever material you want. I printed mine with yellow ColorFabb XT. Just be aware of the risks of bacterial proliferation due to the high humidity and the rough surface of objects produced with FDD printers. I'm not an expert in this field but my own experience shows that smoothing (i.e. ABS smoothing with acetone) significantly reduces the risk.

author: atntias

title: Filament Sample Spool
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The two sides just twist lock together, no glue or screws needed. Center hole is 35mm in diameter. Should be printable with about 14.2 meters of 1.75mm filament ( less than a standard filament sample from maker box of about 16m) going off of the estimate from my slicer (xyzware pro). Pics above show the remainder of the filament after printing only the spool and the type of filament, though I see no reason why this couldnt be printed with any type of filament. settings I am using of are 0.2mm layers, 3 shells, 3 top layers, 3 bottom layers, and 10% infill. The infill is somewhat important because there will be 4 layers of it on both sides of the spool. You can print it solid but will not be able to get both peices out of one roll of sample filament then.
The two parts are not in the proper printing orientation, not exactly sure why, I design them upright but then they seem to get flipped when converting to stl. Also only print the files ending with pt1 and pt2

In testing I found out that not all sample rolls have the same inner diameter. I measured all 32 samples i have and found 12 that would fit a 130mm spool, 13 at 120mm, and 6 that need 110 or less. I sized the roll to just under 120 mm since that was the most common, but the sides are still tall enough that the outside of a large roll will not slip off. Smaller samples will just need to be wound onto it by hand. I may make a small drill attachment for doing this winding in the future if this seems to be too much of a pain to do by hand.

title: Minimalistic soap stand
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is what happens when you need a soap stand because your soap keeps on slipping around, you have no time for choosing your preferred design online, but you have a fairly easy CAD handy along with a good 3D printer.
The fences on the lower side help draining the water away.
Minimum design effort, but does the trick for me. For more than a year now.

Notes:

Just print the part with your favorite printer using the default orientation from the STL (drain fences upper side).
Source file is provided (format: Geomagic Design) if you need to change anything.

Because of the risks of bacterial proliferation given the humid environment of the bathroom, and the rough surfaces produced by FFD 3D printers, I prefer to print this with a material that you can easily smooth. I printed mine in ABS and I smoothed it with acetone vapors. The stand is wet all the time, but no signs of mold so far. And the smoothing made the plastic look & feel like porcelaine.

Warning: acetone vapors are toxic and dangerous. Be sure you know what you are doing. There are plenty of tutorials online on how to do acetone smoothing safely.

title: Amiga 500 Gotek USB disk drive emulator base

description.text:
These items create a base for the well known Gotek USB disk drive emulators used in Amiga 500 computers.
There is no need to cut the Amiga computer case, and the buttons and USB port can be accessed and used easily.
Also the disk drive button port will be covered so no hole is being left.

The support cylinders are not really needed because the whole Gotek structure is not that heavy. The are two versions included on with a pin which can be pointed downwards and the other side can be glued/screwed to the base structure.
The other cylinder has a screwhole on both sides.

comments.text: Finally got around to fitting this yesterday. GREAT design, and overall I was happy with the printing service. I had to file a very small amount from the display aperture (i'm talking a tiny amount), and I could probably do with taking a little off the edges of the eject button (which I see you modified in a later model) but didn't. I used the cylinders and screwed into them, but a bit of hot-glue may have been better just to give a little play. It's a very tight fit, and the existing drive and power cables are stretched to their limit, so I may replace them with the longer ones I was using when the GOTEK was outside of the case. These are not issues with the build though, obviously! I'm really, really pleased with the cradle - thanks so much for designing it, and I'd say as long as anyone doesn't mind a bit of filing to get rid of any rough edges, the printing service is good.

title: Ruger Precision Rifle Magazine Release Extension

description.text:
This is definitely a work in progress!

Here we have an extension for the mag release of the Ruger Precision Rifle. I've included pics with both the AR-10 mags as well as the AICS mags to show where it lands when each magazine is in the rifle. It's attached using a M3x6 bolt and washer. The hole is off-center and the "short" side faces "up" towards the rifle. That should be obvious by the cant of the part. I printed it in red so it'll stick out a little better in the pictures.

Designed with Fusion 360, and I've included the F360 file if folks want to mess with it, and by all means, please mess with it!

As I work on the design, I'll upload newer versions. This is currently v.4.

remixed_from.author: andreasL
remixed_from.title: Axe Z pour smartrapCore (alternative Z axis)

description.text:
The goals of this printer are simple to take as many parts from my Prusa i3 and turn them into a CoreXY printer and if my design failed I could simply rebuild the Prusa print new parts and try again. This means the motors, the linear rods, and electronics are all reused and left in their original state.

The frame will originally be made from 0.5" MDF. Later I will be releasing a frame made with HobbyKing aluminum extrusion.

So what was added new? Well an E3D hot end without a doubt! As well as the linear bearings have been replaced with bushings. The head unit has holes that are universal to fit both direct drive and bowden and possible a laser later.

This printer is not a 100% original or 100% a simple remix. It is a blend or different ideas and different printers.

All the files for the printer can be seen at OnShape and they will be updated from time to time.
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/49a05930080e666fde9d2387/w/c5c347e96b8ab061dbf1a81c/e/e4dc13665934bc55e8ed2eed

title: Dominion Strike Force (15mm scale)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Trans-Universal Dominion, a ubiquitous organization in our Wayfarer: Things Beyond Wonder RPG sessions. This collection of models (mostly re-sized/based versions of our 18mm scale stuff) was printed on a Form2 and is most ideally printed using a similar method (though if you can get these to work on an FDM machine, I'd love to see the make!). We're in the process of overhauling our Wayfarer-Tactics system (soon to be re-released as "Discord") and hope to provide character unit stat cards for all fo the pieces we produce. Stay tuned for news on that front, and shoot us a message if you're interested in beta-testing our wargaming rules (they work with any miniatures).

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...)

Enjoy!

comments.text: Ah, one more question: do you ever print your humanoid figures with FDM printers anymore? I'm using a Printrbot Simple Metal, and I always find it awkward to print models that come attached to a base; I generally end up mesh-mixing them to have the base and model separate, so that I don't have support material trapped in between the two.
comments.author: Mooseral

comments.text: I do in 18mm scale, but we generally get the best results printing them split in half and gluing them together. That retains the most detail, if you don't mind a seam, and if I'm not bothering to paint it, the seam doesn't bother me. I think of them more like plastic army men than "miniatures." We love playing with those though, because there's no pressure (you don't have to worry about things breaking/paint chipping). But, I do love playing with our painted 15mm and 28mm models too.
comments.author: Mooseral

comments.text: OK, so if one of your models has files with the "split in halves" approach, those are already optimized for FDM to some degree, whereas other file types should need a bit more work to make work cleanly. Good to know!
comments.author: dutchmogul

comments.text: Ah, yeah. Sometimes I remember to put that in the print settings area, but I'm not great about that. Haha. But yeah, we split almost all of our 18mm figures (aside from a few that actually print standing without support).
comments.author: Mooseral

comments.text: Hello dutchmogul,
comments.author: Mooseral

comments.text: Good question. Yeah, there's definitely a distinction. I use the "height to eyeline of an average human model" method, which seems to be the most common (and has really silly, arcane origins). The 15mm stuff I generally print in resin (for human-like characters) and I fully paint all of that. The 18mm scale stuff is a bit bigger, and we color code those by filament, don't bother to paint them. These are the models we toss in a box and use on RPG nights, and it's sort of the sweet spot I found for print time-detail ratio.
comments.author: Mooseral

comments.text: "silly, arcane" definitely describes how miniature scales are handled... Precise scaling factors like 1:72 or 1:144 are really how it should be done, but all too often even models using those systems aren't consistent...
comments.author: dutchmogul

comments.text: So silly, and people end up interpreting it to mean something else (hence the gradual scale creep). We thought about starting fresh, which is sort of what we did with our 18mm stuff (we almost called it "PT Scale," for "Pocket- Tactics) but I want to be able to use my 15s and 28s with all that industry standard stuff. That was important to me.
comments.author: Mooseral

comments.text: You could work out what scale industry 15mm and 28mm actually are, adhere to that scale, but then lock it in as 1:60 (or whatever it actually is) or "PT Scale" or whatever you like? Basically, use "their scale" and keep compatibility, but then redefine it precisely with less subjective criteria than the "height to eyeline of an average human model" method.
comments.author: dutchmogul

comments.text: I have to think that others have tried (and failed) in this endeavor, haha. Bottom line, as long as I can use my stuff with Khurasan/Splintered Light, et cetera, or with Reaper/Warhammer, I'm good. Honestly, I do a lot more eyeballing of designs next to existing miniatures than anything.
comments.author: Mooseral

title: Battery Frame Clip and Stand for Mini Drones

description.text:
Small quadcopter drones (in the 90 mm to 100 mm size range) are getting very capable and fun to fly. But the batteries only last a few minutes, so you'll need a bunch of them. This clip is designed to allow quick change-out of the battery while holding it securely in place during flight -- and requires no sticky tape or "velcro"! It also provides quick repeatable accurate battery placement, which avoids the need to retune drone flight characteristics after each battery change. And it provides a useful stand for take-offs and landings. The clip is the orange piece shown in the example photos.

To install the clip on a drone, squeeze the round grip rods lightly to spread the "fingers" far enough to fit on the bottom plate of the drone (see the pictures for hints on placement). The bottom plate should fit in the middle of the clip fingers. After the clip is installed (not before!) on the drone, batteries can be popped in and out of the clip (the batteries fit just above the round grip rods, as shown) while the clip remains attached to the drone. No other attachment method or assistance is needed. The clip is very lightweight, and does not impair the drone's flight performance.

This model was designed and tuned specifically for the Eachine Tiny QX95 95mm Micro FPV Racing Quadcopter with Camera, using 1S batteries from 500 to 720 mAh capacity. To fit other similar quadcopters, the model can be resized up to 10% in any dimension and should retain all critical functions.

This model is designed to be printed on its side, per the orientation in the source STL file. The function of the model, including strength and flexibility, depends on the tensile strength of the extruded filament in the planar directions (parallel to the print bed). The model will fail quickly if re-oriented to flex across the interlayer axis (the Z axis in the source STL file).

Because of this printing orientation sensitivity, the contact edges of the model on the print bed are small -- so you need to set up your 3D printer to have very good printing contact adhesion on the print bed for the duration of the print.

Printer:

PolyPrinter 229

Rafts:

This model is designed to be printed on its side, per the orientation in the source STL file. The function of the model, including strength and flexibility, depends on the tensile strength of the extruded filament in the planar directions (parallel to the print bed). The model will fail quickly if re-oriented to flex across the interlayer axis (the Z axis in the source STL file).

Because of this printing orientation sensitivity, the contact edges of the model on the print bed are small -- so you need to set up the 3D printer to have very good printing contact adhesion on the print bed for the duration of the print.

I printed the model at 0.20 mm, but it will work fine at 0.25 mm too (and may actually be a little stronger).

title: E3D V6 Hotend Mount for Rostock Max V3 & Orion Deltas

description.text:
These parts enable you to mount an E3D V6 hotend to your SeeMeCNC Rostock Max V3 or Orion delta. It is designed to incorporate parts from the HE280 hotend, particularly the PCB that houses the accelerometer which now comes as standard in both printers. Apart from a few extra fasteners, this is all you need to mount a V6 on your SeeMeCNC printer that looks good and involves minimal fuss. Please see the .txt notes file for details and tips on assembly. IMPORTANT: the HE280 has a 0.5mm nozzle, the V6 comes with a 0.4mm nozzle - you must change this setting in your slicer once the V6 is installed or your prints might fail.

FOR V2 OWNERS: This is compatible with the Rostock Max V2 - however you will need to buy the V3 hotend whip and accelerometer board from SeeMeCNC.

Big thanks to those of you who have found this Thing useful and have sent tips to me, they are very much appreciated.

comments.text: Resineer YOU ROCK!! This is SPOT ON! I am using with the E3D Volcano, the only difference in the V6 is the heat chamber itself. The Volcano heat chamber is a little bigger and is not much more money. To make things easier I screwed the board to the holding plate prior to soldering, one less thing to worry about wires getting in the way. For me this up grade is a no brainer I can print one .72 width .30 height with a .6 Nozzle at INSANE speeds 80 mm/s. I must admit that is not for a detailed part but at 70mm/s I still printed the mount and it came out very nice. Thanks again for your contribution to the community!!!
comments.author: MoldMaster

comments.text: I'm glad you're finding it useful :). I will be developing a new version soon that uses improved box fans and an LED light ring. I want to run a 0.8mm too at some point, so I'm glad this works with the Volcano.
comments.author: MoldMaster

comments.text:
Not sure I like the light ring idea. If I don't need it on and on the machine for the machine to work than I don't need it attached to the machine. I have LED Spot lights 120V (cheap ones from Harbor Freight) that I control from a smart switch. I have had a couple of prints break loose from the bed WHEN I WASN'T IN THE OFFICE and I can shut power off from the z-wave plug. Most of my prints end up completing when I am not in the office, so I like to be able to shut things down where ever I may be. I have the z-wave plugged into my battery back up along with the WIFI camera and yes my Router is plugged into another battery backup. If I know for sure how long a print will be I set my smart hub to turn that plug off at a certain time, then sleep with no worries!
I am sure your new design will be fantastic!
comments.author: Resinseer

comments.text: Don't worry the light ring effector will be optional. Mostly I just want to integrate the more efficient box fans, the stock fans are kinda crappy even with the shrouds.

comments.text: Well, I finally got around to installing my accelerometer, whip, v6, and your mount.  Only problem is, my effector warped on my first test!  I printed it on Bridge at 80% infill 3 layers top bottom and sides.  HE only got to 240 deg, fan was working.
comments.author: Resinseer

comments.text: I'm sorry that you've had trouble with it, I've had no other reports like this and mine works great. The HE mount is designed so that the nozzle is in the exact same Z position relative to the arms as it is with the HE280. Without looking at your parts it's hard to diagnose. Mine is PLA with 1.2mm walls with 25% ish infil. Try again with different settings and see if you can improve it, I'm sure it's possible as quite a few people are operating this without any issues.
comments.author: Thingismith

comments.text: Very strange...I wonder if it might have something to do with my bed, I've got the heat up to 90 deg.  I'm really surprised you printed it on PLA, it's such a fragile material.
comments.author: Resinseer

comments.text: The PLA one was a prototype, I was going to print it in a much stronger material but it worked well enough that I haven't bothered yet. I'm going to build that effector down the line too, that was an awesome remix of this mount. I'll be using atomic carbon PETG, just need to order some scroll fans. I'm sure you're figure it out, but thanks so much for feeding back - this may get quite widely used so it's goof to know about potential bugs.

comments.text: Auto calibration still works fine, as that is done by the accelarometer circuit board which fits onto this mount. Also, the nozzle Z position on this mount is exactly the same as it is on the HE280. So just fit it, re-calibrate and you're good to go.

comments.author: wwendorf

comments.text: What is the advantage of this hot end vs. the HE280? I like it out so far.
comments.author: kirbyand

comments.text: The nozzle selection from SeeMeCNC is limited, and the nozzles are more expensive than the E3D. I primarily use 0.35mm, which SMCNC doesn't offer with the V3 hotend.
comments.author: kirbyand

comments.text: Thanks for your reply! Wow 9?! You must be doing this professionally. I will consider a different fan configurations. I'll check yours out. What is the design difference with the E3D? The HE280 Heating block looks very similar.
comments.author: Djkirkendall

comments.text: Externally they look similar, but the machine finishing on the E3D is of a much higher standard which aides plastic flow, and also the heatbreak design is different which again aides flow and means you can print at lower temps reliably than with the HE280. It's just more trouble free in general really.
comments.author: kirbyand

comments.text: The HE280 is quite good, but with the E3D V6 you can print at faster speeds (around double, I have found) without risking any filament starvation problems like missing layers etc. It is also generally more reliable and consistent, according to most people who have used both extensively.
comments.author: kirbyand

comments.text: No problem :), the community has helped me so much and it's nice to be able to give something back.

OpenLOCK is an Open-source scenery connection system. OpenLOCK is designed for use by skilled 3D modellers who want to make scenery that is compatible with Rampage System and other OpenLOCK systems. OpenLOCK is an Open-source scenery building system developed by www.printablescenery.com

This file set compliments http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1833963

This is the new OpenLOCK side connector tiles that will be part of the OpenLOCK 5.0 update. The Side Connector tiles allow you to build complex structure and mitigates the need for the D,C,B,QC,QA and QB Walls. It also allows you to build separate corner columns such as buttresses

title: Lasercut utility rack/shelf for Ikea Bekvam kitchen island.

description.text:
A lasercut MDF storage system I quickly whipped up in Visio so I could store away the tools and clutter that I regularly use with my 3D printer, instead of having them strewn around the dining room table.

Sized for the short width of an Ikea Bekvam kitchen island, which I use as my 3D printer stand. Formatted for cutting on 3mm MDF cut 24" x 18" (Arch C sheet size) - I do all my work on an Epilog Helix. I have provided the PDF and a SVG file that I converted online at https://cloudconvert.com/vsd-to-svg. Shared as is.

If you are inclined to be more than a taker and a consumer, pay forward by contributing to this site, as so many others have before you, or perform a random act of kindness, or donate to a good cause when the opportunity next arises. If you liked it enough to download it I'd appreciate a LIKE, it helps get the word out and spread these designs around. That is all.

title: Geeetech i3 replacement x axis ends

description.text:
I recently had to replace my x ends on my i3b, downloaded a set and found then to be to narrow (21mm rod & thread rod distance), so decided to create my own, hope they are useful.
Just added a further 2 variations of end stop mount, so now the endstop can go front, back and below depending on needs.
the x end stop is designed to house a mini micro switch 13mm x 6mm
other items required are :-
m4 nut
m4 bolt 30mm (preferably hex dome cap screw)
m3 lock nut
m3 bolt 20mm
gt2 idler pulley gt2-16t-b3 (16 tooth, 3mm bearing centre as pictured above.

comments.text: Is there a reason you don't use the idler method of putting the tension on the end of the rods? E.g. smooth x-axis and others. I tried 'smooth x-axis' for our printer's spacing, but it had some flaws in the design where the lead-screw nut mounts.
comments.author: agaskins

comments.text: They go go the opposite way up to the originals, I may of forgotten something on the ones I uploaded I'll ch ck out what you mean get back to you and correct what ever is wrong, but on my machine they work perfectly, I also had troubles with the smooth axis design, the spacing of lead screw and lmu8 bearing carrier was to close together, also the tensioner mount is built in onc assembled it works fine, only think I can find I missed was I should of pot the rod holes straight through on tensioner end so it works the same as the original geeetech, where you fit lockers to stop the rods sliding through.
comments.author: agaskins

comments.text: Nothings wrong at all, just a different methodology, and one that I think you might prefer once you see it. It greatly reduces the effect the lead-screw/threaded-rods have on the x-axis because all the tension is places on the rods from the belt tensioner, and the other end is pressing on the motor end (you already have the motor end right for this by not letting the rods go in but so far).
comments.author: Blank_Disk

comments.text: so there's zero force pulling the ends together, and you don't need the rod clamps with this setup
comments.author: agaskins

comments.text: I only mention it because I think you'd have the best design around for geeetech users with this one feature, and while I'm learning to design things... I don't know that I'm up to a full x-axis design haha. I admire your talents to do this! Please don't misunderstand me, haha.
comments.author: agaskins

comments.text: If you look at the original x ends they actually stop the rods moving through the ends as they are capped, the holes don't go all the wat through thus taking force away from x ends, but I do understand exactly what you mean the x ends would have slight freedom to move, the only thing is that may effect accuracy and that's always my goal, as when I first had my printer it were not to accurate so I made many changes to improve it, as for comments, I take them all as constructive, useful to know if something functions correctly.
comments.author: agaskins

This is the first prototype of my 3d mouse. It was created to test out the precision of the sensors and lacks a grip and buttons. To see it in action:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=taLBV3AzXNk
in stereoscopic 3d:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xyEZV3lYuxE I am using a Phidget I/O board and 3 of their potentiometers. The demo program was created in python using the phidget library, pygame, and pyopengl. To hold it on to the table I am using Rotoscan's Clamp with some Sugru for grip:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12616 I think for now I will explore the software side of things, I'd like to integrate alternative input support into Blender 3D, and maybe try to use Kinect to see what the quality of 3d tracking is. The reason I created this now is that I have actually wanted to create this several years ago (before Kinect, before Arduino), and had the Phidget i/o board and potentiometers sitting in storage for a long time and the difficulty for me was in creating the frame, and now that I have a 3D printer it is much easier to create things like this.

Bill of Materials:
1 USB Phidget i/o board, one that can connect 3 or more sensors.
http://www.phidgets.com/products.php?category=0&product_id=1018_2
3 potentiometers that work with the i/o board.
http://www.phidgets.com/products.php?category=37&product_id=1109_0
And of course you need a 3d printer to print the parts.
And a PC to run the software. Software:
7zip to decompress the bird.7z file (which has arm.py the software in the video):
http://www.7-zip.org/
To run the arm.py:
you need python (I built with 2.x, not 3.x):
https://www.python.org/downloads/
You need the phidget drivers and python libraries:
http://www.phidgets.com/docs/Language_-_Python#Quick_Downloads
You need pyopengl:
https://pypi.python.org/pypi/PyOpenGL
And pygame:
http://www.pygame.org/download.shtml The potentiometers in this design act as the connecting joints, so you will need 3 of them to put this together. The bird.7z archive has everything you need. The STL files, the original OpenSCAD files and the demo python script. The files are designed to fit snug for my potentiometers with my Red PLA plastic. I had added holes for screws but didn't end up needing them because it was snug. You will likely need to update the OpenSCAD files to fit your potentiometers. If I do an update, I would probably make it easier to do this, but for now it is going to require a bit of work and testing to see what works for your pots. Once you have it hooked up you will need to calibrate the demo by recording the values for the angles at 0 and 90 degrees and modifying the demo script. In the demo sensor 0 is the base, sensor 1 is the neck and sensor 2 is the arm. 0 degrees presents the base is forward and the other joints are all pointing upward.

Lighter than original alloy parts for gopro gimbal that is sold by a dodgy chinese company with 'luck' in the middle of their company name.  
I have printed all these parts and have them on my copter.  Saves about 70-80 gram of weight against the original alloy parts.  
Best to have the fill set high (80%) to stiffen the parts up and also 2 shells and .15 height.  
I used ABS.  
To save using supports, the motor mount holes will need drilling through.  The holes are all correct but are not all the way through.   
I have uploaded the STL files.

Having one solid part without the screws will decrease weight and increase precision i guess.

title: Luno Tri Spinner + Design Tutorial - Public Domain

description.text: My take on a more traditional style tri spinner. Public domain license, so feel free to do with as you wish. Standard 608 bearing size. I've also included the 123D Design sketch that I used to make it and a quick tutorial.

Super easy design. If you want to play around with it, I've attached the 123D Design sketch that I used to make it. Follow the steps below and reference the attached screenshot to recreate this spinner. This tutorial assumes you know how to navigate 123D Design. If you are completely new to 123D Design, check out this quick 7 part video series from shapeways.
https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLB1379Ylrc1r-UwRBcCEPpPNUfCG-f2qq

You also need to understand that there are 360 degrees in a circle and to evenly space bearings on a tri-spinner, they need to be placed 120 degrees apart.

Create the Spinner!

To view a large size of the image, right click the image and select "View in new tab"

Step 1 - Create the center bearing circle cutout using sketch circle. I set the diameter to 22.1mm as I find it works well.

Step 2 - Draw a line(sketch polyline) from the center of step 1 outwards to the right and down at a 30 degree angle. Set the line length to 25mm

Step 3 - Draw a line from the center of step 1 outwards to the left and down at a 30 degree angle. Set the line length to 25mm.

Step 4 - Draw a line outwards straight to the top and set the line length to 25mm. You now have the center locations for your bearing cutouts. See the drawing 1 in the image.

Step 5 - Use sketch circle on each center location to make 22.1mm diameter circles.

Step 6 - On the same perimeter bearing centers, use the sketch circle tool again and create 28.1mm diameter circles. This gives our bearings a nice rugged 3mm wall. You could make these 26.1 if you want thinner 2mm walls. See drawing 2 in the image

This is now almost complete. Technically you could put a 28.1mm circle around the center bearing and have a spinner, but let's make the curved indents now.

Step 7 - Basically you need to repeat steps 2-4 above. However this time you will be drawing lines between the existing circle centers. All lines should be at 60 degrees apart.

Step 8 - On the non-bearing centers, use the sketch circle to create 21.9mm circles. This makes the non-bearing circles intersect the walls of the bearing circles. See drawing 3.

Step 9 - Delete the guidelines from the center. Just click on the line and press delete. This makes it easier to select objects to extrude.

Step 10 - Select just the bearing walls and the space between the bearing walls and the center bearing cutout. You can select multiple objects by holding shift and then clicking. See drawing 4.

Step 11 - Once all the objects are selected, click the gear and select extrude. Set the extrude distance to 7mm. Hold left click on the extruded model and drag it away from the sketch. See drawing 4 and 5.

You should now have a rough spinner 3d model! Now let's finish it!

Step 12 - Select Modify and then Fillet. Now select the top and bottom outside edge of the model, again using shift to select both at the same time. A box at the bottom of the screen will pop up. Input 1.3 and hit enter. See drawing 6.

That's it! Your spinner is now complete and you've completely recreated what I have here. If you made it here, CONGRATS!

title: Lego replacement cover for Chevy Colorado Card holder

description.text:
This is a replacement plate for the card holder in newer Chevy Colorado's. I put this into my 2015, no idea what other years it fits. If someone wanted to download the model and modify it, I'm sure the Lego points can be removed and it can be reconfigured to have switch mounts added for towing purposes. I printed my in ABS and made the Lego points .1 mm larger in diameter for shrinkage, and it worked great. The knobs on the back were made so that no additional metal brackets would be needed to hold it in the dashboard.

28AUG17 - Added IGES files for the file, and a second one with no LEGO studs on the front
SolidWorks

I made this by reverse engineering the shape and measurements of the factory plate. title: FLUX Delta Spool Holder - 2 Piece Design

description.text:
This filament holder is designed to clip on the corner of your FLUX delta printer and to hold a full sized spool of filament horizontally. It prints in 2 parts so that there aren't any overhangs or supports to worry about, and you feed the spool rod through the base "claw" to assemble it. You could glue these two pieces together, if you like.

I saw coco966's design, and read about some of the printability issues that people were having, so that inspired this 2 piece design.

Designed with DesignSpark Mechanical - RSDOC source file is included.

8/9/17 Update - Split parts into separate files, per community request.

Printer:

Prototype

Notes:

Use SpinRodSmall for spinning the spool on center (easier to turn for little stepper motor)
Use SpinRodLarge for spinning the spool off center (harder to turn for little stepper motor)

Printed in Simplify3D, almost everything is .250 layer with 20% infill, except for the threads i made the threads with .100 layer and 20% infill, Simplify3D allows for .250 layer and .100 layer to exist in a single program by using more than one process, process1 is .250 layer for the lower section of part and process2 is .100 layer for the upper section of the part, this allows for quicker printing and high quality threads, these threads go together good, the female thread is 110% larger then the male thread.

I also used Cooling/Speed Overrides/Adjust printing speed for layers below "15.0 sec", Allow speed reductions down to 20%" (Simplify3D). This is what i call "active cooling" it basically prints slow in certain areas to keep the print high quality, it makes the threads better, and prints faster when it can.

title: Volkswagen VW Golf MK5 R32 badge

description.text: This is a replica badge that i designed for my VW MK5 R32 Golf. I bought a replacement black badge online but is was absolute shite (eBay strikes again) so thought i'd make my own.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

FlashForge Creator Pro

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.18

Infill:

100

Notes:

I printed it upright as it give a smoother finish, however this does make the badge not as strong as printing it flat on the bed. It also uses far less support material when printing upright.

For some reason Simplyfy3D does not properly display/print this badge. FlashPrint & ReplicatorG slice and support the model perfectly.

For the ABS version i used acetone vapor for around an hour, this seem to be just enough to smooth out the layers and give nice gloss finish.
I also used acetone on the red PLA version, this didn't smooth out the layers but did add a shine to it, almost looked like a candied badge!

I didn't add the badge clips in the design so using some sticky-back foam strips works very well. Strong enough to hold on the car but not too tough remove if desired.

I used 3DS MAX to design this badge. I took measurements of my orginal badge using a caliper, the only thing that is not exactly the same is the clips on the back, i opted for a smooth back and just used sticky pads to hold it on the car.

This is a basic tonearm lifter design for all those record players that are fully automatic (Such as the Pro-Ject series, as well as many others).
I designed it because I kept forgetting that I left the needle on the end grooves of the record, and I wanted the needle to lift off when the record was done.
It is a work in progress - is too sensitive to set, but not sensitive enough to be activated by the touch of the tonearm every time. It also lifts the tonearm too high for a lid to be on at present, and does so with a bit of a kick.

  1. Print both pieces, flat
  2. Attach rubber band to end of lifter and bottom cylinder
  3. Using glue or (recommended) blutak, stick it to the desired spot on your turntable where you would like the tonearm to be lifted.
  4. Set it by pulling the lifter down and forward onto the small lip

title: Frsky X12S "Eye of Horus" Roller Button

description.text:
I didn't care for the factory roller button on the Frsky X12S Transmitter so decided to have a little fun designing/printing a replacement.

Now my Horus has a proper eye.

Printer:

Original Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

I used Simplify3D to slice this and printed with full raft and custom supports to keep the bottom of the button clean. I ended up using two different processes, one for the button body and then one with a narrower extrusion width and higher infill overlap for the eye detail as Simplify3D would only print the outlines with no infill using my standard settings.

I also adjusted the inner diameter of the hole and flat for the switch shaft to work best with my slicer and printer. It took a couple of iterations to get right and may need further adjustment depending on which slicer and/or printer you use. I included a step file along with the stl to hopefully make that easier.

description.text: This thing is a quick relese mounting plate for a Manfrotto 785B camera tripod.

Updates:
2012-04-07 First version.
2012-04-08 Changes to design after new measurements. Added .scad file. The idea is to make custom mounts to be able to use the tripod for other devices than cameras. This is a work in progress which hasn't been tested. I haven't printed this to try out how well it fits in the tripod, I have only measured the original tripod mounting plate using a caliper and then modeled the thing from that, using OpenSCAD. Therefore there is a distinct possibility (probability...) that it will not fit the tripod without digital or physical tweaking. So be warned, angles may be wrong etc.

I had a 3 piece painting and needed to hang it up on the wall - problem is it hangs sideways and i didnt want to put two screws in the wall for each piece. So here is a hanger that straddles the middle piece and also hooks it to the wall.   
Spread between the bottom part is 36mm - each foot is 19.2mm deep.  
I broke a couple when trying to mount them with the drill, just use a screwdriver and they go up great.

description.text:
Print the 2020 bracket and spool spindle in ABS 100% infill and then acetone weld them together.

Update 2017 March
I've had spools that didn't fit nicely on the old one so I created a new one that uses a TPU cushion that allows all spools to work.

New TPU (ninjaflex) spool cushion works much better than previous stepped design. Print with 15% infill so it is extra flexible.

New spool base is also wider to support even more spools. I printed this in PLA with 40% infill.

Note, with the wider base, the TPU cushion could be optional but it does help align the spools.

Make you project glide with these linear drawer slides, made with airsoft pellets as ball bearings.
Materials needed:
3D Print
Airsoft Pellets
Lighter/Match
WD-40

Instructions:
Line up the chamfered holes so they are facing each other.
Insert 4 airsoft bearings into each side
Slide the inner rod 90% on till the hemispheres in the front of the rails are half covered
Insert a bearing in to each of the hemispheres in the front and pull the rod
Pull the rod forward till the hemisphere on the back of the rod are half covered
Insert 2 bearings into the back of the rod.
Pull the rod all the way forward till it stops
Using a match or lighter heat up the back tab until it is soft and pliable
Using the match stick or stick flip the tab up to lock the assembly in place
A few drops of WD-40 on the bearings goes a long way.

Caution Hot Things are Hot

title: Aikon and X-Racer ESC Guard/Protector for the FloRotors Roosh

description.text:
Aikon and X-Racer ESC Guard/Protector for the FloRotors Roosh
(Aikon HV and 2-4s 30A + X-Racer Quadrant 25A)

Racing drones make components break... A lot. I'm notorious for getting prop strikes on my ESCs and rendering them useless. I have an ESC graveyard because of this.

So, I designed this with a few things in mind:

  • Easy ESC release for rapid repair
  • As light as possible
  • Reinforced where it needs it

The thinking can be adapted to all ESCs. This particular file is sized for the Aikon HV 2-6s Lipo ESC and it has the zip tie hole for the FloRotors Roosh arms.

https://www.florotors.com/products/roosh-5l
http://www.buddyrc.com/aikon-sefm-30a-high-voltage-esc-with-blheli-s-program.html

This has saved me plenty already.

This is a DG Logo. I took my Freinds Drawing and made it into a 3d Design. Any tips are greatly appreciated and will go towards the creation of future projects.

This problem started out with the question: How can you sweep a triangle through a circular path such that the point of the triangle points "out" at the top and sides but "in" at the bottom?

This requires us to select a function that gives the angle of the triangle relative to the angular position within the circle. The requirements give four fixed points which the function must hit but otherwise leaves it open. This particular model uses a linear piecewise connection between these points. Although the simplest possible solution to these conditions, it also seems to give the most aesthetic final product.

Two different wireframe spacings are provided.

title: Anet A8 5 Button to Encoder Button change

description.text:
Update 27-MAY-2017
Added the SkyNet 2.3.1 headers and sources I modified. Note that these sources include auto leveling 3DTouch changes. Again, please note that these are SkyNet 2.3.1 changes.
---- End Update ----

There’s probably many other ways to convert from the 5 button display to an encoder button, but most of the conversions I’ve seen ended up with the original display location unused and the display sitting in a printed mount (to quote Sienfeld; "Not that there’s anything wrong with that.") My primary motivation is to free up pins on the Mega1284P. I’m currently using an SN04 proximity sensor for auto leveling, and it’s working fine for printing PLA on blue painters tape, but I’d like to move to printing ABS on glass, and to do that I need a different leveling sensor. I looked at several different proximity sensors, most were either too expensive or they didn’t have the range to go through 4mm borosilicate glass (the SN04 when used at 5V only has a range of about 1.2mm, and 4mm at most at 12V). The other sensor option is to move to a servo probe, and for that you need another pin. After searching the Sanguinololu schematics (the Anet v1.0 board), as far as I could tell there are no available pins, all are used (with the possible exception of 27/A4). I also wanted a clean place to plug in the probe servo, and the back of the display panel seems like a logical location. So, I decided if I’m going to build my own display board (that would fit an A8), at the same time I would move to an encoder button, and to do that you need two more pins. To free up pins I converted the 2004 display to an I2C display. This frees up 6 pins, 3 for use by the encoder button, one for the servo for the probe, and 2 for future use.

Prints:
Cover, encoder button, plugs to fill front panel holes.

Materials:
(2) 60 x 80mm double sided proto boards.
(1) PFC8574 I2C LCD serial interface board
(1) 2004 LCD (without the serial interface board already attached)
(2) 4.7K resistors
(1) rotary button encoder.
(1) 5x2 2.54 double row header or a 5x2 IDC header.
optional: (1) XH2.54-3P Connector Header for the probe servo.

Start by bonding the two proto boards together (see photo). I used the thin strips left over from XH crimp pin coils to bridge the gap, but any thin flat solderable material will work.
Enlarge the top left and top right holes to 3.5mm. When drilling the 3.5mm (or larger hole, depending on how much leeway you may need), start from one side, don’t drill all the way through, then finish from the other side to avoid tear out.
Use the original A8 display back plate as a drilling template for the bottom left and right holes. I first drilled 1mm pilot holes and then enlarged them with the 3.5mm bit.
Apply the headers per the photos using the row column locations on the proto boards.
Locate the encoder on the board and test fit to see if it aligns with your A8.
Locate and test fit the I2C interface board/2004 LCD.
Wire the board based on schematic in the attached Display_Sch.pdf. I used 30AWG wire wrap wire for everything except for the servo.

If anyone actually builds one of these and you aren’t sure how to adjust the headers for SkynetV2.3.1, contact me and I’ll give you the headers/sources for you to diff.. I also noticed and fixed a bug in the code that handles the encoder. The bug is that when you press the encoder button from the info screen, it takes several tries to get to the menu. The fix to SkynetV2.3.1 ultralcd.cpp moves the resetting of the "timeout to move back to the info screen" to the point where the encoder button is initially pressed rather than after the button bounce delay finishes. It looks like someone already fixed this in the latest Marlin sources (lots of changes).

Other:
PFC8574 I2C LCD serial interface board: I bought a bunch of these a few years ago, but any PFC8574 board should work. http://www.ebay.com/itm/IIC-I2C-TWI-SPI-Serial-Interface-Board-Module-Port-for-Arduino-1602LCD-G-/262573103427?hash=item3d22939943:g:e48AAOSw-itXrD7D
Rotary Button Encoder: Again, I bought several of these a few years ago. This appears to be the same as what I have: http://www.ebay.com/itm/3Pcs-6mm-D-Shaft-18-Position-360-Degree-Rotary-Encoder-w-Push-Button-LW-/171816111876?hash=item280109cf04:g:Gg4AAOSwiwVWT4Qs

The probe I used: https://www.aliexpress.com/item/Free-Shipping-Geeetech-Auto-Leveling-Sensor-3D-Touch-for-3D-Printer-Improve-Printing-Precision/32761924885.html?spm=2114.13010608.0.0.cNqcsb

The bracket I designed for it: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2135749

description.text:
I didnt like many of the dog holders I had seen on here, and after my store bought one broke, I decided to try my hand at creating my own! I modeled this off my broken one, so it should fit pretty much all standard sized dog bags. It has two little recesses in the body and clips on the cap, so it shouldn't have any issues with falling apart. I added a bottom opening for those that like to dispense the bags that way.

Supports are pretty much required both pieces, at least with my printer and experience, but use your best judgement. I printed mine upright with supports, not on their sides.

The lid is a pretty tight fit, but this can vary between printers and how you have things calibrated. Mine definitely, 100%, will not come off by accident. Use a Carabiner or something similar to attach it to your leash. Heck, print a matching one from some of the great carabiner clips on this site!
I might adjust this print in the future so it isnt quite as tight of a fit, or Ill change it to a screw top. Not sure. May even have the hook loop as a separate piece that is glued on for those not wanting to use as much support material.

title: Servo Motor Vehicle Steering Mount - Arduino basic kit.

description.text:
This is the 2nd part of my remote control vehicle project for the basic arduino intro kit.

I did the stepper/drive motor assembly, this is the servo/steering assembly and chassis.

It's really light weight - as an experiment I don't want to wait an age for experimental stuff that doesn't work! And I may use its flexibility as an integrated suspension/shock-absorber structure.

It takes the basic kit servo adds a steering assembly and links to my stepper/drive assembly.

Printer:

Reprap Prusa i3 2017 model (from kit)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

The chassis is long and thin - one leg did lift from the plate a bit during printing, but its not really precision stuff, so it didn't matter too much.
Everything is supposed to be a tight fit, so it may need filing out depending on your printers/filament.

FreeCAD

I tried to make a load of rack type setups, but didn't want extra hardware and couldn't get reliable push fit pivots from my PLA (I got some good ball/sockets, but it was all too random).

I settled on a really simple direct servo/axle link - its only a prototype thing, so I can live with it - but everything on the front wheels goes directly to the servo.

The servo fits below the 'chassis' bit so doesn't need screwing in, the holes in the back of the chassis link to my previous axle assembly thing.

description.text:
The camera mount included with the Blink set is quite clever, in that it can be adjusted to cover most angles, but perhaps it just doesn't look so cool to me, so I decided to design and print my own mount based on the classic spherical bearing mechanism, just because ;)

Even though I made this specifically for the Blink cameras, nothing prevents you from using it with any other camera or thing. Just make an adapter that can be screwed or glued to the arm of this mount and voilà!

As usual I'm including not only the STLs but also the original SketchUp project file, so feel free to modify it to your liking (eg. maybe you need a larger arm, or a larger contact area with the wall). Commercial use of this model is explicitly forbidden by the license though.

Printer:

XYZ DaVinci 1.0 (modded)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Easier to print in PLA if your printer supports it.

Inserting the ball into the socket should take some force for a good fit. If the arm is too stiff once inserted in the socket you can always sand the parts down a little bit, or perhaps put a drop of oil in the ball. If, on the contrary, the fit is not tight enough, then the arm will not hold in position with the added weight of the camera. In that case you should try tweaking your slicing settings or, worst case, scale the model (up or down, depending which part you choose to re-print) accordingly by a bit, say 3%. Trial an error should get you a good fit eventually.

Use either a small screw or glue to attach the adapter for the backplate of the camera to the square end of the mount's arm. I've had mixed experiences 3D printing this adapter though. Sometimes it'd come out with a perfect fit, only to have the next print be either too loose, or impossible to insert, or it'd end up cracked. Best thing you can do is, if you still have them, use the original piece that comes with the Blink camera backplate instead of the 3D printed version. You can easily drill a small hole on it in order to fix it to the arm with a screw. Or, again, just use some strong glue.

Finally, attach the mount to either a corner or a flat wall (use the flat version of the socket model for this) with some strong double-sided tape. I always use Tesa Powerbond for this sort of task and it performs extremely well even on surfaces you wouldn't expect it to (but boy is it expensive!).

After I bought an H&K 416C, I didn't want to use the included PEQ box, and I wanted to have an angled foregrip. I designed this foregrip to have a small compartment for a 11.1V LiPo stick battery.

Version 1

was far too large, it's handstop was too small, and the holes for zip ties were poorly designed. Additionally, the grip was acceptable, but it was still a little slippery.



Version 2

is a step in the right direction, but it still isn't perfect. It's profile is much cleaner, the holes for retaining zip ties are perfect, the handstop is beefy, and the recesses and texturing on the sides make the foregrip easy to hold. However, I'm not completely satisfied.


In the next version,

expect to see a more ergonomic profile, a battery retainer that isn't a zip tie, and no more holes on the profile.

Suggestions

I want to hear them. If you have any ideas, comment!

MakerBot

description.text: This is a Ferrari style case for the Iphone 5S or Iphone SE. It is designed to print in ABS to allow it to flex some but also be rigid. Right off of the print bed, it was a bit tight in some places, so I just used an exacto knife in those places to shave a little bit off, and then it fit beautifully. When putting the phone in the case make sure to insert the sleep/wake button on the top, and the volume, and slider on the side of the phone into the slots on the case first before putting the rest of the phone in. To take it out, just push the phone out a little bit through the Ferrari logo on the back, and then at the bottom of the phone work it out until the bottom is out of the case. Then just slide it out. It goes in and out very easily, but also stays in the case wellI also added a lip to the case to keep the screen from ever touching anything (like the top of the desk when you put it down). Overall, I think you will really like this case, and it is perfect for any car fan!!

Aroundsquare is proud to introduce the Titan OS (open source) Begleri, the latest in the Titan Begleri series. This is a free-to-download 3D print file that will allow enthusiasts to cheaply and easily print their own set of Titan begleri, and even tweak the design to their own personal tastes. Aroundsquare is making this design available for free to the community, in the continued efforts to help grow the begleri community and put good quality, high performance begleri in the hands of as many players as possible.

If you don't know what begleri is, start here: https://youtu.be/4yZC1inesPY
And if you want to learn how to play, start here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LBVcqOSqntQ&list=PLcH_xQ-HtxrdzkoPZHxShywhPLrmeP6nE

In August 2016, Aroundsquare introduced the Titan Begleri, with an innovative design that maximizes smooth play and bead control. The Titans have become firmly established as a classic and community reference standard against which other begleri are compared. The original Titan begleri were introduced in titanium as a high end, premium product, and were soon followed by the Titan AL Sport series, a more economic aluminum alternative sporting the same design features. Aroundsquare is proud to now make this same basic design freely available for players and enthusiasts to print or adapt for their own use. The design has been adjusted slightly in both size and shape to make it suitable for commonly available 3D printing materials, and to make it relatively straightforward to print. Many thanks, and a great deal of respect to Alexander German for his support in the development of the model and prototypes.

The Titan OS design, like all AO2 content, is available under creative commons: CC-BY-SA.

title: PT01 Scratch NIM Prototype v2.2 - Mini Innofader Mount

description.text:
Say hello to the NIM!

Free to download PT01 Scratch Mini Innofader mount.

Our way of giving back to the portablism community, the NIM will be available free to download here at thingeverse, so you can print it in your own or nearest 3D printer and 3D printer HUB service.

No 3D printer? No problem!

Just download the file and look for your nearest 3D Hub printer in 3dhubs.com you should be able to print it for about $8 usd or less!

Instructions

Because of the 90 degree overhang this print should be printed with a Support, the 3D printer operator should be able to change and adjust the support material density, fill amount, type of support, fill percentage, etc.

This support should be able to be removed from the print by braking or separating the support or in other advance cases dissolved the support material.

v2.1

Added sink holes for screws that are too short to reach the thread on the metal, I use larger screws so I don't have that problem.

v2.2

Shorten the height so the PT01S lid can close properly.

description.text:
Teaching aids and ornaments based on thing:2069650 and thing:2081305. They also make an interesting mobile.

The five diagrams explain the suns movement at latitutes of 0, 23, 33, 42 and 51 degrees. The ornaments add a representation of the sun to the diagrams.

The idea for these models and ornaments comes from a discusssion of Solstices and Equinoxes on the geomancy web site - http://www.geomancy.org/index.php/astronomy/orthographic-projections

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3 mm

The diagrams are versions of the dxf files at thing:2081305 with bolder lines and marks. The circle, which represents the horizon, is marked at 10 degree intervals. The line cutting the solstices and equinox represents an arc which runs from north to south. It is marked at 10 degree intervals. The arcs representing the solstices and equinox are marked at 15 degree intervals. The positions of the marks on the arcs are foreshortened by projection but can still be used to determine altitudes and hours of daylight. See thing:2081305 for more information.

title: Hex maze projection
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
It's based on Hex maze pyramid and the stereographic_projection in my stereographic things.

It doesn't matter that the hex maze is not a square. Actually, all kind of shapes can be projected.

Find my things about stereographic projection in stereographic_projection.

Find all my mazes in the collection "maze generators".

  • OpenSCAD Documentation - Traditional Chinese
  • OpenSCAD Documentation - English

Do you want to know how to create mazes with OpenSCAD? The following documents may help.

  • Manual maze
  • Binary tree algorithm
  • Random maze

My library dotSCAD has a stereographic_extrude module. You can use it to create a thing of stereographic projection easily.

I'm in the process of creating an enclosure for my prusa i3 mk2 and I've gone the lack table way that seem to be popular. I've been looking at all the different filament guides, they seem to be mostly small holes or long narrow holes. Both make sense.

I'm going to be bringing my internal height of the enclosure up to 18" with the addition of printed parts that double for holding the acrylic sides in place. I've been told that the small hole would be a detriment to taller prints so the long hole would work better. This is where my idea came in, with the wider cone base that goes on the underside and the small hole at the top the pivot point of the filament is raised an additional 1.5" which should be enough with the extra height of the enclosure to allow for a small hole right at the top. At least that's my theory, still to be tested. I wanted the small hole to keep the ABS vapors in the box as much as possible.

I designed the bottom for a 2.5" hole (cause I have a hole saw bit that size). It should screw into the bottom, then the top piece should just fit inside the bottom piece from above, some glue if you want (I didn't).

My approach seems to have worked, I just screwed up the dimensions on the hole size (modeling newb mistake) for the larger cone. It 'fit' but I obviously need to downsize the cone, i'm betting by the thickness of the cone walls.

Updated the files with better dimensions now. Outside of the cone is 2.5", so a hole saw of that size will work well.

This is no longer untested. I have run several prints through and moved the filament full left and right at full height, works well. Note: my enclosure height (bottom of the cone) is at 18" exactly, as this is the precut height of the acrylic that I purchased and designed my risers around.

Paired with my filament spool holders I feel like I've got a well working system in place.

description.text:
I have four of these frames and I've always liked to race with them.
You can pick one up here: https://www.liftrc.com/lrc-racex
The only problem with these drones was the limitation of only having room for crappy CMOS cameras. This mount changes that and allows you to mount a full HS1177 FPV camera on that frame, and if printed with TPU it should survive many crashes. As is it will fir the original 2.8mm lens, and my favorite 1.8mm lens from Banggood. Additional cuts may have to be made depending on your battery strap location. I attached the original 3D file if you want to edit it further. Made with FreeCAD

remixed_from.author: MatthewUpp
remixed_from.title: MP Select Z-Axis Bracket - Don't Download - See Details

description.text: This is technically a remix of this design MP Select Z-Axis Bracket. by kingofl337. I redesigned it to accommodate shorter 12 mm socket head M3 screws for easier install. I also added a bit more tolerance to the fit of the back hex nuts. You'll need to print two setts of these for top and bottom of the rails.

Printer:

MP Select Mini

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

100 microns

Infill:

40%

Notes:

I used higher amount of infill so the part would cut down on vibration.

Installation

These are pretty easy to install. once you have the two z-axis panels off. if you need help with that. Life and Times of Tyler makes some really great videos.

I used some screws and nuts I got from Inventables.

  • M3 12mm length 0.5mm pitch Socket-head screws
  • M3 0.5mm pitch nuts
  • No washers needed

To make installing these easy I dropped the hex nuts in the back bracket part and put a piece of masking tape over them to temporally hold them in place

I Installed the top bracket in place but loosely installed the bottom bracket in the middle then slid it down into place before tightening it. Tighten each screw a bit then go back and tighten again until they are a bit hard turn.
